elements.content: A anionic zinc­(II) metal–organic framework (MOF) {[(CH3)2NH2]­[Zn­(FDA)­(BTZ)2]} n (1) (H2FDA = furan-2,5-dicarboxylic acid and HBTZ = 1H-benzotriazole) was synthesized under solvothermal conditions. This MOF demonstrates a rare planar 4-connected usf topology and exhibits high thermal and chemical stabilities. Postsynthetic cation exchange of 1 with Cu2+, Co2+, and Ni2+ afforded a series of mixed-metal loaded MOFs: {[(CH3)2NH2]­[Zn x M1‑x (FDA)­(BTZ)2]} n (M 2+ @1) (M2+ = Cu2+, x = 0.59; M2+ = Co2+, x = 0.83; M2+ = Ni2+, x = 0.58). More importantly, 1 is investigated as a turn-off luminescent probe to sensitively and selectively detect acetylacetone with the detection limit of 0.647 μmol/L, which demonstrates the first anionic framework as a luminescence probe for effectively recognizing acetylacetone.

elements.content: There has been continuous interest in recognition and sensing of organic small molecules because of their important roles in environmental implications, humanitarian threats, and homeland securities. In spite of more convenient to sophisticated analytical instruments, new molecules that are capable of fast and reliable recognition have been identified. Nevertheless, the significant defects of high cost, low sensitivity, and poor selectivity still remain a great challenge. Actually, the emerging metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) may provide a facile route to cross the obstacle of the above defects and have attracted extensive attention for their superior multifunctional performance in luminescence, gas storage and separation, and heterogeneous catalysis. The combination of luminescence and accessible porosity for MOFs can endow them with the capability of detectable changes in their luminescence by the transformation of alternative guest motifs via the host–guest interactions and provide an opportunity of promising candidates for chemical sensing applications. Consequently, much work has been devoted to synthesizing such luminescence MOFs for their chemical sensing applications.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

There has been continuous interest in recognition and sensing of organic small molecules because of their important roles in environmental implications, humanitarian threats, and homeland securities. In spite of more convenient to sophisticated analytical instruments, new molecules that are capable of fast and reliable recognition have been identified. Nevertheless, the significant defects of high cost, low sensitivity, and poor selectivity still remain a great challenge. Actually, the emerging metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) may provide a facile route to cross the obstacle of the above defects and have attracted extensive attention for their superior multifunctional performance in luminescence, gas storage and separation, and heterogeneous catalysis. The combination of luminescence and accessible porosity for MOFs can endow them with the capability of detectable changes in their luminescence by the transformation of alternative guest motifs via the host-guest interactions and provide an opportunity of promising candidates for chemical sensing applications. Consequently, much work has been devoted to synthesizing such luminescence MOFs for their chemical sensing applications.

elements.content: It is well-known that acetylacetone is widely utilized as intermediates of organic synthesis, analytical reagents, and other essential raw ingredients. However, the improper disposal of them will cause serious human health and environmental problems, and the effluent limitations and standards have been listed by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA). In particular, acetylacetone is volatile and flammable, and its excessive exposure in air is suspected to the culprit of safety hazard. Therefore, this could seek the employment of a luminescent MOF as probe to sensitively and selectively detect acetylacetone, which however has rarely been reported.

Therefore, this could seek the employment of a luminescent MOF as probe to sensitively and selectively detect acetylacetone, which however has rarely been reported.

elements.content: Herein, a rare usf zinc­(II) MOF {[(CH3)2NH2]­[Zn­(FDA)­(BTZ)2]} n (1) (H2FDA = furan-2,5-dicarboxylic acid and HBTZ = 1H-benzotriazole) has been synthesized, which demonstrates high thermal and chemical stabilities. Moreover, the facile postsynthetic cation exchange approach was utilized to fabricate series of mixed-metal loaded analogous MOFs of 1 by incorporating Cu2+, Co2+, and Ni2+ ions into 1: {[(CH3)2NH2]­[Zn x M1‑x (FDA)­(BTZ)2]} n (M 2+ @1) (M2+ = Cu2+, x = 0.59; M2+ = Co2+, x = 0.83; M2+ = Ni2+, x = 0.58). Additionally, 1 was exploited as a luminescent probe to selectively detect acetylacetone with low detection limit and high quenching constant, belonging to the first example of anionic framework for sensing acetylacetone.

elements.content: All reagents and solvents were purchased from commercial sources and used as received without further purification. Elemental analyses of C, H, and N were performed using a PerkinElmer 240 CHN elemental analyzer. IR spectra were recorded in the range 400–4000 cm–1 with a Bruker Tensor 27 spectrometer on KBr disks. Powder X-ray diffraction measurements were carried out using a D/Max-2500 X-ray diffractometer with Cu/Kα radiation. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out using a Delta Series TA-SDTQ 600 in a nitrogen atmosphere from room temperature to 800 °C (10 °C min–1) using aluminum crucibles. The luminescence spectrum was measured on a Varian Cary Eclipse Fluorescence spectrophotometer. UV/vis spectra were recorded on a Agilent Cary100 spectrophotometer. SEM-EDX mapping measurement was carried on a FEI Quanta650. inductively coupled plasma (ICP) was recorded on a Varian-720.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Methods and Materials

All reagents and solvents were purchased from commercial sources and used as received without further purification. Elemental analyses of C, H, and N were performed using a PerkinElmer 240 CHN elemental analyzer. IR spectra were recorded in the range 400-4000 cm-1 with a Bruker Tensor 27 spectrometer on KBr disks. Powder X-ray diffraction measurements were carried out using a D/Max-2500 X-ray diffractometer with Cu/Kα radiation. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out using a Delta Series TA-SDTQ 600 in a nitrogen atmosphere from room temperature to 800 °C (10 °C min-1) using aluminum crucibles. The luminescence spectrum was measured on a Varian Cary Eclipse Fluorescence spectrophotometer. UV/vis spectra were recorded on a Agilent Cary100 spectrophotometer. SEM-EDX mapping measurement was carried on a FEI Quanta650. inductively coupled plasma (ICP) was recorded on a Varian-720.

elements.content: The suspensions 1-solvents were prepared by introducing 5 mg of crystalline powder 1 into 4 mL of water, CH3OH, C2H5OH, CH3CN, THF, DMF, DMA, CH2Cl2, 1,4-dioxane, glycol, and acetylacetone, respectively. After ultrasonication for 30 min, stable suspensions for fluorescence investigation were formed. For sensing acetylacetone molecules, 5 mg of crystalline powders 1 was dispersed in 3 mL of DMF, forming stable suspensions, and then 2% acetylacetone DMF solution was added slowly. For the anti-interference ability of 1, 5 mg of crystalline powders 1 was dispersed in 3 mL of DMF, forming stable suspensions, then 100 μL of the corresponding solvents were added to the DMF suspension of 1, and the corresponding emission spectra were monitored. With the subsequent addition of 100 μL acetylacetone into the parallel tests, the corresponding emission spectra were monitored. The UV–vis spectra of H2FDA, HBTZ, acetylacetone, and suspension of 1 at the concentration of 0.5 mmol·L–1 in DMF were recorded.
elements.clean_text:
Preparations of the Suspensions 1-Solvents 

The suspensions 1-solvents were prepared by introducing 5 mg of crystalline powder 1 into 4 mL of water, CH3OH, C2H5OH, CH3CN, THF, DMF, DMA, CH2Cl2, 1,4-dioxane, glycol, and acetylacetone, respectively. After ultrasonication for 30 min, stable suspensions for fluorescence investigation were formed. For sensing acetylacetone molecules, 5 mg of crystalline powders 1 was dispersed in 3 mL of DMF, forming stable suspensions, and then 2% acetylacetone DMF solution was added slowly. For the anti-interference ability of 1, 5 mg of crystalline powders 1 was dispersed in 3 mL of DMF, forming stable suspensions, then 100 μL of the corresponding solvents were added to the DMF suspension of 1, and the corresponding emission spectra were monitored. With the subsequent addition of 100 μL acetylacetone into the parallel tests, the corresponding emission spectra were monitored. The UV-vis spectra of H2FDA, HBTZ, acetylacetone, and suspension of 1 at the concentration of 0.5 mmol⋅L-1 in DMF were recorded.

elements.content: Data collection of 1 was performed using an Oxford Supernova diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo–Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The temperature was cooled by a CryoJet controller attached to an Oxford Supernova diffractometer. The structures were solved by direct methods. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined by full-matrix least-squares techniques on F 2 using the SHELXS-97 and SHELXL-97 programs. Anisotropic thermal parameters were assigned to all non-hydrogen atoms. The hydrogen atoms were placed in idealized positions and located in the difference Fourier map. The composition of the as-synthesized 1 was calculated based on the element analysis, TGA, and single crystal structure. CCDC 1819499 for 1 contains the supplementary crystallographic data of this paper. The data can be obtained free of charge from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif. The crystallographic data for 1 are summarized in .
elements.clean_text:
Crystallographic Study

Data collection of 1 was performed using an Oxford Supernova diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The temperature was cooled by a CryoJet controller attached to an Oxford Supernova diffractometer. The structures were solved by direct methods. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined by full-matrix least-squares techniques on F 2 using the SHELXS-97 and SHELXL-97 programs. Anisotropic thermal parameters were assigned to all non-hydrogen atoms. The hydrogen atoms were placed in idealized positions and located in the difference Fourier map. The composition of the as-synthesized 1 was calculated based on the element analysis, TGA, and single crystal structure. CCDC 1819499 for 1 contains the supplementary crystallographic data of this paper. The data can be obtained free of charge from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif. The crystallographic data for 1 are summarized in .

The solvothermal reactions of zinc nitrates with H2FDA and HBTZ in a 1:3 mixture of C2H5OH and DMF at 160 °C afforded the crystals of 1, where H2FDA were completely deprotonated, generating uncoordinated sites of FDA2– ligands, and the counterions are protonated dimethylammonium cations, formed from the decomposition of N,N-dimethylformamide. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction study revealed that 1 crystallized in the trigonal system with space group R3c (). As shown in a, there is one crystallographically independent Zn­(II) ion, one FDA2– ligand, one BTZ– ligand, and one dimethylammonium cation in the asymmetric unit. Zn1 is tetracoordinated by two oxygen atoms (O1 and O4A) from two FDA2– ligands and two nitrogen atoms (N1 and N3A) from two BTZ– ligands, generating a distorted tetrahedron {ZnN2O2} coordination geometry. The Zn–O bond distances range from 1.975(3) to 2.027(3) Å, and the Zn–N bond distances are in the range of 1.992(4) to 1.995(4) Å, which are in good agreement with those reported previously. Interestingly, the H2FDA ligand was completely deprotonated during the crystallization of 1, forming FDA2– with the coordination mode of η1-η1-μ2 and resulting in the uncoordinated site of FDA2– ligand (Figure S1 in the Supporting Information). The HBTZ ligand was deprotonated as well with the coordination mode of η1-η1-μ2. As a result, one FDA2– ligand and one BTZ– ligand connect one Zn2+ ion into a 3D anionic framework (b) in which dimethylammonium cations play an important role of counter cations to keep the whole framework neutral. The 3D anionic framework is composed of voids of 1822.5 Å3, presenting the solvent-accessible volume of 25.6%, calculated by PLATON with the removal of dimethylammonium cations.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Description of the Crystal Structure

The solvothermal reactions of zinc nitrates with H2FDA and HBTZ in a 1:3 mixture of C2H5OH and DMF at 160 °C afforded the crystals of 1, where H2FDA were completely deprotonated, generating uncoordinated sites of FDA2- ligands, and the counterions are protonated dimethylammonium cations, formed from the decomposition of N,N-dimethylformamide. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction study revealed that 1 crystallized in the trigonal system with space group R3c (). As shown in a, there is one crystallographically independent Zn(II) ion, one FDA2- ligand, one BTZ- ligand, and one dimethylammonium cation in the asymmetric unit. Zn1 is tetracoordinated by two oxygen atoms (O1 and O4A) from two FDA2- ligands and two nitrogen atoms (N1 and N3A) from two BTZ- ligands, generating a distorted tetrahedron {ZnN2O2} coordination geometry. The Zn-O bond distances range from 1.975(3) to 2.027(3) Å, and the Zn-N bond distances are in the range of 1.992(4) to 1.995(4) Å, which are in good agreement with those reported previously. Interestingly, the H2FDA ligand was completely deprotonated during the crystallization of 1, forming FDA2- with the coordination mode of η1-η1-μ2 and resulting in the uncoordinated site of FDA2- ligand (Figure S1 in the Supporting Information). The HBTZ ligand was deprotonated as well with the coordination mode of η1-η1-μ2. As a result, one FDA2- ligand and one BTZ- ligand connect one Zn2+ ion into a 3D anionic framework (b) in which dimethylammonium cations play an important role of counter cations to keep the whole framework neutral. The 3D anionic framework is composed of voids of 1822.5 Å3, presenting the solvent-accessible volume of 25.6%, calculated by PLATON with the removal of dimethylammonium cations.

elements.content: A further investigation on the intricate framework of 1 was achieved by topological analysis using the freely available TOPOS software package. As shown in c, the Zn mononuclear unit can be treated as distorted square planar 4-connected node, which links two FDA2– and two BTZ– ligands and each FDA2– and BTZ– ligand is regarded as a 2-connecter, which is linked by two Zn mononuclear units. Consequently, the structure of 1 can be simplified as a uninodal 4-connected net with the Schläfli symbol of (65·8) (d), corresponding to the usf topology. As far as we know, there are also a number of reported 4-connected nets with planar nodes, including NbO , CdSO4 , lvt , qzd , and mot . Nevertheless, the usf topology of 1 is clearly different from other reported network topologies and is rarely observed in MOFs. To the best of our knowledge, only one example with usf topology is observed in the structures of isostructural neutral MOFs {[M2(bdc)2(Q)2]} n (M = Co, Cu, Zn and Q = quinoline). Therefore, 1, Cu 2+ @1, Co 2+ @1, and Ni2+@1 represent the first examples of a class of anionic frameworks that possess a usf topology.

elements.content: Direct synthesis of the substitutive analogue of 1 by partially or absolutely substituting Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O with M­(NO3)2·6H2O (M2+ = Cu2+, Co2+, and Ni2+) in the synthesis of 1 described above was frustrated. As we know, the postsynthetic modification of MOFs via metal ions exchange can provide an opportunity of an alternative to the conventional introduction of functional species into MOFs that cannot be introduced by direct solvothermal synthesis, while the structural integrity of the MOFs can still be retained. Thus, the postsynthetic approach via metal ions was utilized to synthesize such analogues of 1. The process of exchanging the central Zn2+ ions with other divalent metal ions (e.g., Cu2+, Co2+, Ni2+, Cd2+, Mg2+, Ca2+, Mn2+, and Ba2+) was investigated. The powder of 1 was immersed in methanol solutions of the corresponding nitrate salts for 4 days. The powder colors changed rapidly in the corresponding M­(NO3)2·6H2O (M2+ = Cu2+, Co2+, and Ni2+) (Figure S2 in the Supporting Information). The ICP (Table S1 in the Supporting Information) showed that only the process of exchanging the central Zn2+ ions with Cu2+, Co2+, and Ni2+ could be performed, while the central Zn2+ ions could not be replaced by other divalent metal ions, such as Cd2+, Mg2+, Ca2+, Mn2+, and Ba2+: Approximately 41%, 42%, and 17% of Zn2+ was exchanged by Cu2+, Ni2+, and Co2+, respectively. Moreover, the substitute of Zn2+ with Cu2+ and Ni2+ is more facile than the substitute of Zn2+ with Co2+. This may be due to the approximate ion diameter and flexible coordinating modes between Cu2+, Ni2+, and Zn2+. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) of the resulting Cu 2+ @1, Co 2+ @1, and Ni 2+ @1 is in good agreement with the simulated 1 (Figure S3 in the Supporting Information). This fact indicated that the resulting Cu 2+ @1, Co 2+ @1, and Ni 2+ @1 is isostructural to 1 and that the substitution of Zn2+ with Cu2+, Co2+, and Ni2+ is successful, further confirmed by SEM-EDX mapping measurements (Figures S5–S7 in the Supporting Information).
elements.clean_text:
Cation Exchange

Direct synthesis of the substitutive analogue of 1 by partially or absolutely substituting Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O with M(NO3)2⋅6H2O (M2+ = Cu2+, Co2+, and Ni2+) in the synthesis of 1 described above was frustrated. As we know, the postsynthetic modification of MOFs via metal ions exchange can provide an opportunity of an alternative to the conventional introduction of functional species into MOFs that cannot be introduced by direct solvothermal synthesis, while the structural integrity of the MOFs can still be retained. Thus, the postsynthetic approach via metal ions was utilized to synthesize such analogues of 1. The process of exchanging the central Zn2+ ions with other divalent metal ions (e.g., Cu2+, Co2+, Ni2+, Cd2+, Mg2+, Ca2+, Mn2+, and Ba2+) was investigated. The powder of 1 was immersed in methanol solutions of the corresponding nitrate salts for 4 days. The powder colors changed rapidly in the corresponding M(NO3)2⋅6H2O (M2+ = Cu2+, Co2+, and Ni2+) (Figure S2 in the Supporting Information). The ICP (Table S1 in the Supporting Information) showed that only the process of exchanging the central Zn2+ ions with Cu2+, Co2+, and Ni2+ could be performed, while the central Zn2+ ions could not be replaced by other divalent metal ions, such as Cd2+, Mg2+, Ca2+, Mn2+, and Ba2+: Approximately 41%, 42%, and 17% of Zn2+ was exchanged by Cu2+, Ni2+, and Co2+, respectively. Moreover, the substitute of Zn2+ with Cu2+ and Ni2+ is more facile than the substitute of Zn2+ with Co2+. This may be due to the approximate ion diameter and flexible coordinating modes between Cu2+, Ni2+, and Zn2+. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) of the resulting Cu  2+  @1, Co  2+  @1, and Ni  2+  @1 is in good agreement with the simulated 1 (Figure S3 in the Supporting Information). This fact indicated that the resulting Cu  2+  @1, Co  2+  @1, and Ni  2+  @1 is isostructural to 1 and that the substitution of Zn2+ with Cu2+, Co2+, and Ni2+ is successful, further confirmed by SEM-EDX mapping measurements (Figures S5-S7 in the Supporting Information).

elements.content: As we know, most reported MOFs have insufficient thermal stability in air and lack tolerance toward moisture and many organic solvents, suffering from unsatisfied chemical and/or thermal stabilities, which prevents them from competing with inorganic zeolites in practical applications. As a result, the stabilities of these MOFs should be considered before they are applied. Thus, the chemical stability of 1 was investigated. Compound 1 was immersed in water, CH3OH, C2H5OH, CH3CN, THF, DMF, DMA, CH2Cl2, 1,4-dioxane, glycol, and acetylacetone, demonstrating a tolerance toward moisture and the corresponding solvents and showing excellent chemical stability, which was confirmed by PXRD (Figure S4 in the Supporting Information). The TGA of 1 was also studied under an N2 atmosphere to confirm the thermal stability (Figure S8 in the Supporting Information). The TGA shows a steady plateau from room temperature to 280 °C, indicating that 1 is stable up to 280 °C, and then the whole framework begin to decompose upon further heating. This phenomenon was confirmed by the fact that 1 was heated at the temperature range of 100–280 °C for 0.5 h in air without losing their framework integrity, supported by PXRD ().

elements.content: It is well-known that MOFs comprising d10 metal ions and conjugated organic ligands are regarded as promising candidates in the fields of luminescence materials. The solid luminescence spectrum of H2FDA, 1, Cu 2+ @1, Co 2+ @1, and Ni 2+ @1 have been measured at room temperature (). Upon excitation at 260 nm, the emission spectrum of H2FDA exhibits a main emission with the maximum value of 465 nm, ascribed to π* → π and/or π* → n electronic transitions. Compared to the H2FDA ligand, a similar red shift of ca. 22 nm is observed for 1, Cu 2+ @1, Co 2+ @1, and Ni 2+ @1 upon excitation at 320 nm. Consequently, the emission peaks at 487 nm of 1, Cu 2+ @1, Co 2+ @1, and Ni 2+ @1 appear, assigned to the intraligand π* → π or π* → n transition of the ligand that was perturbed by metal ions.

elements.content: Recently, much work has been devoted to exploiting luminescence MOFs due to their excellent candidates for the rapid recognition and sensing of cations, anions, and small molecules. Of particular concern to the MOF-based luminescence probes comprising d10 metal ions is the favorable advantage in detection fields. In this work, 1 was explored as the luminescence probe to recognize organic small molecules via the luminescence enhancing or quenching effects. The powders of 1 were dispersed into common organic solvents including water, CH3OH, C2H5OH, CH3CN, THF, DMF, DMA, CH2Cl2, 1,4-dioxane, glycol, and acetylacetone by ultrasonic about 0.5 h, generating suspension solutions. As shown in , the luminescence of 1 is significantly dependent on the solvent molecules. Particularly, in the case of acetylacetone, it exhibits the most noticeable turn-off luminescent quenching effect, and the luminescence is totally quenched. Compared with the influence of acetylacetone on the luminescence of 1, other organic solvents have a negligible effect on the luminescence of 1. The above result indicates that 1 can be regarded as a promising luminescent probe for recognizing acetylacetone. The anti-interference sensing ability of 1 has been investigated by the competing experiments (Figure S10 in the Supporting Information). The results also indicated that 1 still exhibited obvious luminescent quenching effects, showing very excellent selectivity to acetylacetone and outstanding anti-interference sensing ability and could be used for sensing in the systems with complicated components.

Acetylacetone Sensing

Recently, much work has been devoted to exploiting luminescence MOFs due to their excellent candidates for the rapid recognition and sensing of cations, anions, and small molecules. Of particular concern to the MOF-based luminescence probes comprising d10 metal ions is the favorable advantage in detection fields. In this work, 1 was explored as the luminescence probe to recognize organic small molecules via the luminescence enhancing or quenching effects. The powders of 1 were dispersed into common organic solvents including water, CH3OH, C2H5OH, CH3CN, THF, DMF, DMA, CH2Cl2, 1,4-dioxane, glycol, and acetylacetone by ultrasonic about 0.5 h, generating suspension solutions. As shown in , the luminescence of 1 is significantly dependent on the solvent molecules. Particularly, in the case of acetylacetone, it exhibits the most noticeable turn-off luminescent quenching effect, and the luminescence is totally quenched. Compared with the influence of acetylacetone on the luminescence of 1, other organic solvents have a negligible effect on the luminescence of 1. The above result indicates that 1 can be regarded as a promising luminescent probe for recognizing acetylacetone. The anti-interference sensing ability of 1 has been investigated by the competing experiments (Figure S10 in the Supporting Information). The results also indicated that 1 still exhibited obvious luminescent quenching effects, showing very excellent selectivity to acetylacetone and outstanding anti-interference sensing ability and could be used for sensing in the systems with complicated components.

elements.content: Actually, MOF-based probes for detecting acetylacetone are still rare and can only be observed in the cation framework {[Zn­(XL)2]­(ClO4)2·6H2O} n (XL = N,N′-bicyclo­[2.2.2]­oct-7-ene-2,3,5,6-tetracarboxdiimide bi­(1,2,4-triazole)) and the neutral heterometallic framework {[Cd3Tb2(btc)4(H2O)6]­(DMF)4·x(solvent)} n . Nevertheless, anionic frameworks as luminescent probes for recognizing acetylacetone have never been reported. Therefore, 1 is the first anionic framework used as a luminescence probe for effectively recognizing acetylacetone.

elements.content: Further explorations on the relationship between the changes of luminescence of 1 and the concentration of 2% acetylacetone were examined in detail as well. As shown in a, the curve showed the relevant changes of the luminescence intensity of 1 could be clearly observed and the quenching effects simultaneously became remarkable, showing an excellent sensitivity for sensing acetylacetone. Moreover, the luminescence intensity of 1 decreased sharply to 57.6% at the concentration of 3.88 μmol/L acetylacetone, and the intensity of 1 decreased to 79.2% when the concentration of acetylacetone reached 10.36 μmol/L. The decreased intensity of 1 with the increasing acetylacetone suggested the presence of the luminescence quenching effect of 1. The relationship between the quenching efficiency of 1 and the concentration of acetylacetone was illustrated in b. As a result, a best fit of I 0/I, and the concentration of acetylacetone was established with a equation of I 0/I = 1.0197 + K sv[acetylacetone] (inset of b), where K sv stands for the quenching constant (M–1), I 0 and I are the luminescence intensities before and after the addition of acetylacetone, and [acetylacetone] is the molar concentration of acetylacetone (mM), respectively. The result demonstrates a linear correlation of luminescence quenching and the concentration of acetylacetone and is in close proximity to the Stern–Volmer (SV) equation: I 0/I = 1 + K sv[acetylacetone]. The average K sv value was calculated to be 1.86 × 105 L mol–1 by the linear regression of the plot, indicating the significant quenching efficiency of 1 after the adding acetylacetone. The detection limits for acetylacetone can be calculated by using 3δ/k, in which δ is standard error and k is slope according to the Stern–Volmer equation with a value of 0.647 μmol L–1 for 1, further indicative of an excellent sensitivity for sensing acetylacetone.

elements.content: The possible quenching mechanism of 1 was explored. The PXRD patterns of 1 after dispersing in DMF of acetylacetone were in good agreement with the simulated one, demonstrating that the 3D frameworks of 1 still remained stable. As a result, the collapse of the framework was not the main reason that resulted in the luminescence quenching effect. Generally, the luminescence of Zn-MOFs mainly originated from the emission of ligand or the energy transformation between ligands and metals due to the d10 electronic configuration of Zn2+. The UV–vis spectra of acetylacetone, H2TDA, HBTZ, and 1 in DMF were measured (). The adsorption bands are located in the range of 260–338 nm for 1, 254–319 nm for H2TDA, and 246–310 nm for HBTZ, which are completely overlapped by the adsorption bands of acetylacetone (219–351 nm), suggesting the presence of competition of photon absorption between acetylacetone and the ligands. Obviously, the light absorbed by the ligands correspondingly reduced, and the efficiency of energy transform of the framework should go lower. Therefore, the possibility of the luminescence quenching is ascribed to the intense absorption by acetylacetone at excitation wavelength, reducing the photon absorption by the organic ligands and affecting the energy transformation.
elements.clean_text:
Quenching Mechanism

The possible quenching mechanism of 1 was explored. The PXRD patterns of 1 after dispersing in DMF of acetylacetone were in good agreement with the simulated one, demonstrating that the 3D frameworks of 1 still remained stable. As a result, the collapse of the framework was not the main reason that resulted in the luminescence quenching effect. Generally, the luminescence of Zn-MOFs mainly originated from the emission of ligand or the energy transformation between ligands and metals due to the d10 electronic configuration of Zn2+. The UV-vis spectra of acetylacetone, H2TDA, HBTZ, and 1 in DMF were measured (). The adsorption bands are located in the range of 260-338 nm for 1, 254-319 nm for H2TDA, and 246-310 nm for HBTZ, which are completely overlapped by the adsorption bands of acetylacetone (219-351 nm), suggesting the presence of competition of photon absorption between acetylacetone and the ligands. Obviously, the light absorbed by the ligands correspondingly reduced, and the efficiency of energy transform of the framework should go lower. Therefore, the possibility of the luminescence quenching is ascribed to the intense absorption by acetylacetone at excitation wavelength, reducing the photon absorption by the organic ligands and affecting the energy transformation.

elements.content: In summary, a novel 3D anionic usf -type Zn-based MOF has been isolated and structurally characterized, featuring good thermal and chemical stabilities. Through the postsynthetic cation exchange approach, the coordinated Zn2+ ions of 1 can be facilely exchanged with Cu2+ ions, Co2+ ions, and Ni2+ ions, generating three analogues of 1 (Cu 2+ @1, Co 2+ @1, and Ni 2+ @1). The luminescent exploration demonstrates that 1 is a versatile turn-off luminescent probe with highly selective and sensitive detection of acetylacetone. Notably, 1 represents the first example of anionic usf framework as the luminescent probe for recognizing acetylacetone, which provides a facile route to design luminescence probes.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, a novel 3D anionic  usf -type Zn-based MOF has been isolated and structurally characterized, featuring good thermal and chemical stabilities. Through the postsynthetic cation exchange approach, the coordinated Zn2+ ions of 1 can be facilely exchanged with Cu2+ ions, Co2+ ions, and Ni2+ ions, generating three analogues of 1 (Cu  2+  @1, Co  2+  @1, and Ni  2+  @1). The luminescent exploration demonstrates that 1 is a versatile turn-off luminescent probe with highly selective and sensitive detection of acetylacetone. Notably, 1 represents the first example of anionic  usf  framework as the luminescent probe for recognizing acetylacetone, which provides a facile route to design luminescence probes.

As we know, most reported MOFs have insufficient thermal stability in air and lack tolerance toward moisture and many organic solvents, suffering from unsatisfied chemical and/or thermal stabilities, which prevents them from competing with inorganic zeolites in practical applications. As a result, the stabilities of these MOFs should be considered before they are applied. Thus, the chemical stability of 1 was investigated. Compound 1 was immersed in water, CH3OH, C2H5OH, CH3CN, THF, DMF, DMA, CH2Cl2, 1,4-dioxane, glycol, and acetylacetone, demonstrating a tolerance toward moisture and the corresponding solvents and showing excellent chemical stability, which was confirmed by PXRD (Figure S4 in the Supporting Information). The TGA of 1 was also studied under an N2 atmosphere to confirm the thermal stability (Figure S8 in the Supporting Information). The TGA shows a steady plateau from room temperature to 280 °C, indicating that 1 is stable up to 280 °C, and then the whole framework begin to decompose upon further heating. This phenomenon was confirmed by the fact that 1 was heated at the temperature range of 100–280 °C for 0.5 h in air without losing their framework integrity, supported by PXRD ().

Luminescence Properties

It is well-known that MOFs comprising d10 metal ions and conjugated organic ligands are regarded as promising candidates in the fields of luminescence materials. The solid luminescence spectrum of H2FDA, 1, Cu 2+ @1, Co 2+ @1, and Ni 2+ @1 have been measured at room temperature (). Upon excitation at 260 nm, the emission spectrum of H2FDA exhibits a main emission with the maximum value of 465 nm, ascribed to π* → π and/or π* → n electronic transitions. Compared to the H2FDA ligand, a similar red shift of ca. 22 nm is observed for 1, Cu 2+ @1, Co 2+ @1, and Ni 2+ @1 upon excitation at 320 nm. Consequently, the emission peaks at 487 nm of 1, Cu 2+ @1, Co 2+ @1, and Ni 2+ @1 appear, assigned to the intraligand π* → π or π* → n transition of the ligand that was perturbed by metal ions.

Chemical/Thermal Stabilities

As we know, most reported MOFs have insufficient thermal stability in air and lack tolerance toward moisture and many organic solvents, suffering from unsatisfied chemical and/or thermal stabilities, which prevents them from competing with inorganic zeolites in practical applications. As a result, the stabilities of these MOFs should be considered before they are applied. Thus, the chemical stability of 1 was investigated. Compound 1 was immersed in water, CH3OH, C2H5OH, CH3CN, THF, DMF, DMA, CH2Cl2, 1,4-dioxane, glycol, and acetylacetone, demonstrating a tolerance toward moisture and the corresponding solvents and showing excellent chemical stability, which was confirmed by PXRD (Figure S4 in the Supporting Information). The TGA of 1 was also studied under an N2 atmosphere to confirm the thermal stability (Figure S8 in the Supporting Information). The TGA shows a steady plateau from room temperature to 280 °C, indicating that 1 is stable up to 280 °C, and then the whole framework begin to decompose upon further heating. This phenomenon was confirmed by the fact that 1 was heated at the temperature range of 100-280 °C for 0.5 h in air without losing their framework integrity, supported by PXRD ().

Luminescence Properties

It is well-known that MOFs comprising d10 metal ions and conjugated organic ligands are regarded as promising candidates in the fields of luminescence materials. The solid luminescence spectrum of H2FDA, 1, Cu  2+  @1, Co  2+  @1, and Ni  2+  @1 have been measured at room temperature (). Upon excitation at 260 nm, the emission spectrum of H2FDA exhibits a main emission with the maximum value of 465 nm, ascribed to π* → π and/or π* → n electronic transitions. Compared to the H2FDA ligand, a similar red shift of ca. 22 nm is observed for 1, Cu  2+  @1, Co  2+  @1, and Ni  2+  @1 upon excitation at 320 nm. Consequently, the emission peaks at 487 nm of 1, Cu  2+  @1, Co  2+  @1, and Ni  2+  @1 appear, assigned to the intraligand π* → π or π* → n transition of the ligand that was perturbed by metal ions.
